title.narrative: Lake Victoria Environmental Management Project (LVEMP) II Civil Society Watchdog Project
Lake Victoria Environmental Management Project (LVEMP) II Civil Society Watchdog Project

description.narrative: The East African Civil Society Watchdog Project for Sustainable Development in the Lake Victoria basin has the overall objective to build capacity of CSOs in collective advocacy and lobbying activities aimed at supporting/enhancing sustainable development policies within the Lake Victoria basin at local, national and regional levels.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2015Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: The overall objective was 'to build capacity of CSOs' of the three networks in collective advocacy and lobbying activities aimed at supporting/enhancing sustainable development policies at local, national and regional level. The specific objectives were revised after the first year after challenges in the LVEMP II implementation by the Lake Victoria Basin Commission (LVBC) to read as follows :- • To periodically establish and document community beneficiary experiences and level of adoption of sustainable land management (SLM) practices under LVEMPII. • To influence the operationalization of East African Climate Change Policy (EACCP) provisions by LVEMPII and other Regional Institutions and within other interventions. • To strengthen EA SusWatch Network‘s institutional capacity for collective quality monitoring, advocacy and watchdog roles for LVEMPII and other interventions in the Lake Victoria Basin
In this regard a website was developed and various publications disseminated for learning, awareness creation and advocacy purposes. Various trainings were done and strategic advocacy tools applied to initiate and sustain a ‘community voice’ in line with the implementation of LVEMPII implementation. Progress was tracked by monitoring of the Community Driven Development (CDD) subprojects from the beneficiaries’ perspective in relation to water conservation and sustainable land management. The collected feedback was summarized into policy briefs in the form of LVEMP II Civil Society CDD Watch printed in English & Kiswahili and also community info sheets printed in English, Luganda, Luo and Kiswahili which are the main local languages around the lake. The advocacy issues in the policy briefs were then presented to the LVEMPII National Secretariats and District level LVEMPII Coordinators during the strategic meetings for onwards processes with their respective government frameworks.
At the implementation level delays were experienced in the realization of the objective related to EACCP mainly because LVBC who were responsible for the enactment of the policy did not manage to have the policy passed at the EAC parliament or the relevant government institutions on time.
In conclusion, although the overall objectives were achieved apart from the one mentioned above (on EACCP), the outcomes could have been better and more articulated if the reporting had gone further to analyze how the changes made at the advocacy level had impacted on sustainable land management and enhancement of community livelihoods which were the overarching issues set out in the project document. This would have enabled the Embassy and Sida to learn and understand how best to support interventions that bring tangible changes at the national and regional levels based on social inclusion at the community level. This kind of information would have given Sweden positive lessons learnt for future cooperation not only in the Lake Victoria Basin but also in the wider region and other Lake Basins in Africa. It was also observed that the project might have missed an important opportunity in forming synergies with like minded organizations that could follow up and lobby with the respective governments to legislate and enact the relevant policies that had resulted from lessons learnt from this intervention.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
